column2: US:
column3: Polish: [ˈtɔruj̃] (listen); German: Thorn) is a historical city on the Vistula River in north-central Poland
column4: and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Its population was 201
column5: 447 as of December 2019. Previously
column6: it was the capital of the Toruń Voivodeship (1975–1998) and the Pomeranian Voivodeship (1921–1945). Since 1999
column7: Toruń has been a seat of the self-government of the Kuyavian-Pomeranian Voivodeship and
column9: is one of its two capitals
column10: together with Bydgoszcz. The cities and neighboring counties form the Bydgoszcz–Toruń twin city metropolitan area.

column1: Toruń is one of the oldest cities in Poland
column2: with the first settlement dated back to the 8th century and later having been expanded in 1233 by the Teutonic Knights. Over centuries
column3: it was the home for people of diverse backgrounds and religions.  From 1264 until 1411 Toruń was part of the Hanseatic League and by the 17th century it was one of the elite trading points
column4: which greatly affected the city's architecture ranging from Brick Gothic to Mannerism and Baroque. In the early-modern age
column5: Toruń was a royal city of Poland and it was one of the four largest cities in the country at the time. After the partitions of Poland it was part of Prussia and later the German Empire. After Poland regained independence in 1918
column6: Toruń was reincorporated into Polish territory
column7: and during World War II was spared from bombing and destruction. This allowed the Old Town to be fully preserved with its iconic central marketplace.Believed to be one of the most beautiful cities in Europe
column8: Toruń is renowned for the Museum of Gingerbread
column9: whose baking tradition dates back nearly a millennium
column10: and its large Cathedral. Toruń is noted for its very high standard of living and quality of life. In 1997 the medieval part of the city was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site. In 2007 the Old Town in Toruń was added to the list of Seven Wonders of Poland.

column1: Toruń is the birthplace of astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus.
The first settlement in the vicinity of Toruń is dated by archaeologists to 1100 BC (Lusatian culture). During early medieval times
column2: in the 7th through 13th centuries
column3: it was the location of an old Slavonic settlement
column4: at a ford in the Vistula river.

column1: In spring 1231 the Teutonic Knights crossed the river Vistula at the height of Nessau and established a fortress. On 28 December 1233
column2: the Teutonic Knights Hermann von Salza and Hermann Balk
column3: signed the foundation charters for Thorn and Kulm. The original document was lost in 1244. The set of rights in general is known as Kulm law. In 1236
column4: due to frequent flooding
column5: it was relocated to the present site of the Old Town. In 1239 Franciscan friars settled in the city
column6: followed in 1263 by Dominicans. In 1264 the adjacent New Town was founded predominantly to house Torun's growing population of craftsmen and artisans. In 1280
column7: the city (or as it was then
column8: both cities) joined the mercantile Hanseatic League
column9: and thus became an important medieval trade centre.

column1: The First Peace of Thorn ending the Polish–Lithuanian–Teutonic War was signed in the city in February 1411 leaving the town in the hands of the Teutonic Order. In 1440
column2: the gentry of Thorn formed the Prussian Confederation to further oppose the Knights' policies. The Confederation rose against the Monastic state of the Teutonic Knights in 1454 and its delegation submitted a petition to Polish King Casimir IV Jagiellon asking him to regain power over Prussia as the rightful ruler. An act of incorporation was signed in Kraków (6 March 1454)
column3: recognizing the region
column4: including Toruń
column5: as part of the Polish Kingdom. These events led to the Thirteen Years' War. The New and the Old Towns amalgamated in 1454. The citizens of Thorn enraged by the Order's ruthless exploitation
column6: conquered the Teutonic castle
column7: and dismantled the fortifications brick by brick
column9: which was used until the 18th century for the gunpowder storage. During the war
column10: Toruń financially supported the Polish Army. The Thirteen Years' War ended in 1466 with the Second Peace of Thorn
column11: in which the Teutonic Order ceded their control over the city to Poland. The Polish King granted the town great privileges
column12: similar to those of Gdańsk. Also in 1454
column15: the King issued the famous Statutes of Nieszawa
column16: covering a set of privileges for the Polish nobility
column17: an event that is regarded as the birth of the noble democracy in Poland
column18: which lasted until the country's demise in 1795.

column2: the city was home to notable personas
column3: scholars and statesmen. In 1473 Nicolaus Copernicus was born and in 1501 Polish King John I Albert died in Toruń; his heart was buried inside St. John's Cathedral. In 1500
column4: the Tuba Dei
column5: which was the largest church bell in Poland at that time
column6: was placed in the church of St. John the Baptist
column7: and a bridge across the Vistula was built
column8: which was the country's longest wooden bridge at that time. In 1506 Toruń became a royal city of Poland. In 1528
column9: the royal mint started operating in Toruń. In 1568 a gymnasium was founded
column10: which after 1594 became one of the leading schools of northern Poland for the centuries to come. Also in 1594
column11: the Toruń's first museum (Musaeum) was established at the school
column12: beginning the city's museal traditions. A city of great wealth and influence
column13: it enjoyed voting rights during the royal election period. Sejms of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth were held in Toruń in 1576 and 1626.

column2: during the Protestant Reformation
column3: the city adopted Protestantism. Under Mayor Henryk Stroband (1586–1609)
column4: the city became centralized. Administrative power passed into the hands of the city council. In 1595 Jesuits arrived to promote the Counter-Reformation
column5: taking control of St. John's Church. The Protestant city officials tried to limit the influx of Catholics into the city
column6: as Catholics (Jesuits and Dominican friars) already controlled most of the churches
column7: leaving only St. Mary's to Protestant citizens. In 1645
column8: at a time when religious conflicts occurred in many other European countries and the disastrous Thirty Years' War was fought west of Poland
column10: on the initiative of King Władysław IV Vasa
column11: a three-month congress of European Catholics
column14: an important event in the history of interreligious dialogue.In 1677 the Prussian historian and educator Christoph Hartknoch was invited to be director of the Thorn Gymnasium
column15: a post which he held until his death in 1687. Hartknoch wrote histories of Prussia
column16: including the cities of Royal Prussia.

column2: the city was besieged by Swedish troops. The restoration of Augustus the Strong as King of Poland was prepared in the town in the Treaty of Thorn (1709) by Russian Tsar Peter the Great. In the second half of the 17th century
column3: tensions between Catholics and Protestants grew
column4: similarly to religious wars throughout Europe. In the early 18th century about 50 percent of the populace
column5: especially the gentry and middle class
column6: were German-speaking Protestants
column7: while the other 50 percent were Polish-speaking Roman Catholics. Protestant influence was subsequently pushed back after the Tumult of Thorn of 1724.

column1: After the Second Partition of Poland in 1793
column2: the city was annexed by Prussia. It was briefly regained by Poles as part of the Duchy of Warsaw in years 1807–1815
column3: even serving as the temporary capital in April and May 1809. In 1809 Toruń was successfully defended by the Poles against the Austrians. After being re-annexed by Prussia in 1815
column4: Toruń was subjected to Germanization and became a strong center of Polish resistance against such policies. New Polish institutions were established
column5: such as Towarzystwo Naukowe w Toruniu (Toruń Scientific Society)
column6: a major Polish institution in the Prussian Partition of Poland
column7: founded in 1875. In 1976 it was awarded the Commander's Cross with Star of the Order of Polonia Restituta

column2: Poland declared independence and regained control over the city. In interwar Poland Toruń was capital of the Pomeranian Voivodeship. During World War II
column3: Germans occupied the city from 7 September 1939 to 1 February 1945. Local people were subjected to arrests
column4: expulsions
column5: slave labor and executions
column6: especially the Polish elites as part of the Intelligenzaktion. From 1940 to 1943
column7: in the northern part of the city there was a German transit camp Umsiedlungslager Thorn for Poles expelled from Toruń and the surrounding area
column8: which became infamous for inhuman sanitary conditions. Over 12
column13: the city fortunately avoided damage during both World Wars
column14: thanks to which it retained its historic architecture ranging from Gothic through Renaissance and Baroque to the 19th and 20th century styles.

column1: Listed on the UNESCO list of World Heritage Sites since 1997

column3: all built from brick
column4: including monumental churches
column5: the Town Hall and many burgher houses. The most interesting monuments are:

column1: The climate can be described as humid continental (Köppen: Dfb) using the isotherm of 0 °C or an oceanic climate (Cfb) because it is there 0.2 °C above the normal threshold of 1961–1990
column2: probably definitively in the second if the data is updated. In general terms
column3: the city passes close to the original boundary and dividing line of climates C and D groups in the west–east direction proposed by climatologist Wladimir Köppen considering that it was in relatively close places. Toruń is in the transition between the milder climates of the west and north of the Poland and the more extreme ones like the south (warmer summer) and the east (colder winter). Although not much different from Kraków and Warsaw
column4: except for the slightly cooler winters and the less hot summers.

column1: Being close to definitely continental climates
column2: it has a high variability caused by the contact of eastern continental air masses and western oceanic ones. This is influenced by the geographical location of the city – the Toruń Basin to the south
column3: and the Vistula Valley to the north.

column7: it will allow to travel between Toruń-East and Bydgoszcz-Airport stations at a speed of 120 km/h (75 mph) in a time of approximately half an hour. In a few years' time "BiT City" will be integrated with local transportation systems of Toruń and Bydgoszcz
column8: thus creating a uniform metropolitan transportation network – with all necessary funds having been secured in 2008.
